Dipladenia Red Riding Hood syn. Mandevilla sanderii Red Riding Hood
value: Evergreen, shrub-like climber with twining branches (2 m) from Brazil. Deep cherry-pink, funnel-shaped flower with a yellow throat. Useful for a low trellis, draped over a low wall, kept as a shrub or for a hanging basket or pot plant. Very sensitive to cold wet soil in winter. Frost and drought sensitive.
Indigenous (Qld and NSW (including Illawarra region of Sydney))

Evergreen tall rainforest tree with a dense canopy (20m x 10m) from Qld and NSW (including Sydney Illawarra region). Large leathery pinnate leaves. Flowers insignificant. Hairy brown fruit capsules. Useful for large gardens as a shade or specimen tree. Bird attracting. Frost sensitive. Additional irrigation above natural rainfall may be required if growing conditions do not replicate natural occurrence.

Evergreen erect shrub with many sub-species (2m x 1.5m) from Qld; NSW (including Sydney) and Vic. Variable sticky shiny linear to oblanceolate leaves. Insignificant flowers followed by small four lobed fruit. Useful screen or fill-in shrub particularly for a bush garden or difficult site. Attractive purple leaf form D. viscosa var. purpurea available. Frost and drought tolerant.
Indigenous (Qld; NSW (Sydney); Vic; New Zealand & Norfolk Island)

Evergreen small erect fern spreading by underground stolons (0.2m x 0.4m) from Qld; NSW (including Sydney); Vic; New Zealand & Norfolk Island. Deeply lobed fronds with a rough texture and serrated edge. Bright pink to red new growth aging to dark green. Useful mass planted in a partly shaded position or in association with a water feature. Needs well composted soil and some shade. Frost tolerant. Additional irrigation above natural rainfall may be required if growing conditions do not replicate the plant's natural occurrence.

Evergreen large leafy perennial (2m x 2m) from Qld and NSW. Linear sword shaped leaves arranged in a rosette . Spectacular brick red flowers borne along a 4m stem. Useful as a feature; mass planted or for contrast in form. Prefers a moist position in well drained soil. Frost and drought sensitive.

Evergreen large leafy perennial (2m x 2m) from NSW (including Sydney). Rosette forming sword-like leaves to 2m long. Giant erect flower spike to 4m high opening to a branched cluster of waxy red flowers in spring and summer. Useful as a feature; mass planted or for contrast in form. Can be slow to flower. Prefers sandy soil. Semi-drought tolerant. Foliage frost hardy; flowers frost sensitive.

Evergreen small branching tree often pot grown as a house plant (3-4m x 2m) from Africa. Erect to arching sword-like leaves. Large sprays of dark red flowers (white inside) on mature plants. Useful for tropical effect in a shaded protected position. Prefers fertile moist soil. Drought and frost sensitive.

Evergreen slow growing palm-like tree with a thick branching trunk (7m x 5m) from the Canary Islands. Stiff bluish grey strap leaves forming rosettes. White bell shaped flowers inside the leaf rosettes on mature plants followed by clusters of orange berries. Useful as a specimen for its unusual form. Prefers a protected sunny position. Frost and drought sensitive.

Evergreen fast growing bushy shrub with slightly spiny pendulous branches (3m x 2m) from Mexico and Brazil. Oval-acuminate light green leaves. Spikes of lilac-blue flowers in summer and autumn followed by yellow berries. Useful clipped as a formal hedge; screen; part of mixed shrubbery or trained as a standard. Bird attracting. Hardy. Severe pruning after flowering encourages flowering on the outside of the bush. Drought and frost tolerant.

Evergreen clump-forming perennial (0.05m x 0.2m) from Mexico. Basal symmetrical rosette of broad fleshy pale silvery blue leaves with red margins. Bell shaped yellow tipped pinkish red flowers on pink stalks in late winter to summer. Useful bedding plant or to form clumps in a gravel or rock garden and mixed with other succulents. Suitable for a pot plant. Needs full sun and well drained soil. Frost sensitive. Drought tolerant.

Evergreen small clump-forming succulent perennial (0.04m x 0.3m) from Mexico. Pale grey green rosette forming spoon shaped leaves with red tips and margins. Yellow and red cup shaped flowers in spring and summer. Useful groundcover in a rock garden or with other succulents. Needs well drained soil. Frost sensitive. Drought tolerant.

Evergreen vigorous upright clumping perennial (1.2m x 0.5m) from the USA. Dark green lance shaped leaves. Large daisy-like rosy purple flowers with raised orange-brown central cones. Useful specimen; as a border or massed in a semi wild garden. Roots and rhizomes used in herbal medicine. Prefers moist well drained fertile soil in full sun. Avoid root disturbance. Remove spent flowers to prolong flowering. Frost tolerant.

Evergreen fast growing mound shaped perennial (1.5m x 2m) from the Canary Islands. Grey-green leaves in rosettes at the end of stems. Intense blue flowers on long spikes above the foliage in summer. Useful for covering banks and vibrant colour display. Suited to coastal positions and salt spray tolerant. Grows well in poor soils. Needs good drainage or prone to root rot. Remove dead flower spikes. Replant every 3-5 years.Frost sensitive. Drought tolerant.

Evergreen thorny shrub (3m x 2m) from Japan. Oval waxy leaves with wavy margins and silvery beneath. Small bell shaped yellow to white fragrant flowers. Useful as a quick growing hedge or barrier. Hardy. Tolerant of salt spray. Drought and frost tolerant.
Non indigenous (Rainforests Qld and northern NSW)

Evergreen medium to tall tree (15-20m x 10m; shorter in an open position) from rainforests of Qld and northern NSW. Tapered glossy green leaves paler beneath with reddish young growth. Perfumed cream flowers with fringed petals followed by egg shaped dark blue fruit. Useful as a specimen or windbreak. Rows can be clipped as a tall hedge. Prefers well drained soil with ample water. Frost and drought sensitive.

Evergreen dense crowned and conical shaped tree (12m x 5m) from Qld; NSW (including Sydney); Vic & Tas. Dark green oblong to lanceolate leaves with serrate margins and occasional bright red leaves. White cup shaped flowers with a fringed edge followed by deep blue berries. Useful as a shade tree or screen. Tolerates a shady position. Bird attracting. Tolerant of all but extreme frost. Pink form available. Drought tolerant. Additional irrigation above natural rainfall may be required if growing conditions do not replicate the plant's natural occurrence.
Indigenous (Qld & NSW (sheltered understorey in Sydney Hawkesbury Sandstone regions))

Evergreen small slender shrub with stiff wiry stems (1m x 0.8m) from Qld and NSW (including Sydney Hawkesbury Sandstone regions). Pointed ovate leaves crowded on the stem. Red with white edged tubular flowers in rows along the stem in spring. Useful for trailing over rocks and for the interest of its flowers especially in a bush garden. Bird attracting. Sensitive to poor drainage. Avoid root disturbance. Prefers a protected position. Prune stems after flowering for compact growth. Frost and drought tolerant. Additional irrigation above natural rainfall may be required if growing conditions do not replicate the plant's natural occurrence.
Indigenous (Qld; NSW (damp heaths on Sydney Hawkesbury Sandstone ); Vic & Tas)

Evergreen small slender shrub with wiry stems (0.6m x 0.6m) from Qld; NSW (including Sydney Hawkesbury Sandstone regions); Vic & Tas. Tiny prickly cup-shaped leaves. White star shaped flowers; sometimes pink tinged abundant in the leaf axils throughout the year. Useful as a feature or mass planted especially in a bush garden. Must have moist well drained soil. Prune stems after flowering for compact growth. Frost and shade tolerant. Drought tolerant. Additional irrigation above natural rainfall may be required if growing conditions do not replicate the plant's natural occurrence.

Quick growing grass (0.6m x 0.15m) from Vic; NSW; WA and Qld. Mauve flower heads over a long period. Useful groundcover mixed with other native grasses particularly as cover plant for slower growing species. Needs high planting density as groundcover on its own. Tolerates poor soil. Drought and frost tolerant.
Non indigenous (Arid areas of all states of Australia)

Evergreen variable shrub (1.5m x 1.5m) from arid areas of all states of Australia. Linear to ovate leaves. Tubular flowers in a long curving peduncle in variable colour including pink; mauve; red; orange or yellow with a spotted throat. Many good forms available as grafted specimens. Prefers a dry climate but tolerant of humid conditions. Needs well drained sandy soil. Drought and frost tolerant.

Evergreen spreading perennial (0.4m x 1.5m) from Central and North America. Narrow lance shaped hairy leaves. Daisy-like white and pink flowers turning mauve in summer. Useful for colour in the perennial garden and window boxes. Potential weed in bushland. Drought and frost tolerant.

Evergreen spreading perennial (0.3m x 0.6m) from western USA. Leaves forming basal rosettes and on ends of branches. Large branched clusters of yellow flowers turning copper with age on almost leafless stalks. Useful for a rock or gravel garden or groundcover over a dry bank. Needs sandy or gravelly well drained soil in full sun. Self sows freely in favourable conditions. Sensitive to high humidity. Frost and drought tolerant.
Indigenous (Qld & NSW (Sydney Hawkesbury Sandstone & Blue Mtns))

Evergreen erect shrub (1.5m x 1m) from Qld and NSW (including Sydney Hawkesbury Sandstone and Blue Mtns). Thick grey green leaves. Pink waxy star-like flowers in spring. Useful specimen for its flowers particularly in a bush garden. Needs perfect drainage and a cool root zone provided by sandstone slabs or thick mulch. Tolerates full sun or partial shade. Frost and drought tolerant. Additional irrigation above natural rainfall may be required if growing conditions do not replicate natural occurrence.

Evergreen rounded but variable shrub (1-2m x 2m) from Qld; NSW (including Sydney); Vic & ACT. Leaves blue-green usually slender oblong or elliptical. Pink tinted buds open to white star-like flowers in spring. Useful for mass planting; feature or informal hedge. Susceptible to white wax scale & sooty mould. Frost and drought tolerant. Additional irrigation above natural rainfall may be required if growing conditions do not replicate the plant's natural occurrence.

Semi-evergreen rosette forming perennial (0.5m x 0.7m) from all states of Australia. Spiny waxy divided narrow leaves forming a rosette with a carrot-like taproot. Branched metallic blue stems with bright blue flowers and long spikey bracts in long lasting globular thistle-like heads. Useful for a specimen in a rock garden; mixed with other perennials for its colour and texture or cut flower. Needs full sun and well drained soil. Drought and frost tolerant.

Evergreen upright shrub (2.5m x 2.5m). Interspecific hybrid between E. bifida and E. x exoniensis from South America. Glossy dark green leaves. Fragrant white flowers with a faint pink flush before opening. Flowering from late spring to autumn. Useful hedge; screen or background plant. Wind and salt spray tolerant. Tolerates light frosts only. Drought tolerant.

Evergreen bushy shrub (3m x 2m) from Chile. Shiny oval deep green leaves. Tubular deep red flowers in groups of about 30. Useful as a fast growing screen; hedge or shelter plant particularly in a coastal location. Dwarf forms available. Wind and salt spray tolerant. Prune after flowering to maintain shape and remove woody growth. Frost and drought tolerant.

Fast-growing, slender, erect annual (0.3 m x 0.2 m) from California. Grey-green, feathery leaves. Shallow cup-shaped single flowers in shades of red, orange, yellow or cream from spring to early autumn. Useful planting in drifts in a semi-wild garden where it can be left to naturalise. Self seeds freely. Prefers sandy, well-drained soil in full sun. Moderately drought tolerant. Frost tolerant.

Evergreen small grafted tree (5m x 3m) on variable rootstock. Hybrid between E. ficifolia and E. ptychocarpa; both from WA. Bronze green broad lanceolate leaves. Large trusses of pink flowers with gold stamens and yellow centres. Useful feature gum tree for the small garden. Bird and insect attracting. Suitable for large containers. Frost sensitive particularly when young. *Known to damage underground services, do not plant within 6 metres of any wastewater pipe.

Evergreen tall tree with a rounded crown and rough grey grainy bark shedding in short ribbons (20m x 10m) from NSW (including Sydney Cumberland Plain) and Vic. Broad bluish green leaves. Cream flowers in early summer. Useful for shade or windbreak in a large garden. Highly fire resistant timber. Frost and drought tolerant. *Known to damage underground services, do not plant within 6 metres of any wastewater pipe.
Indigenous (Coastal Vic & NSW (Sydney Hawkesbury Sandstone region))

Evergreen medium to large tree with spreading crown and flaky fibrous bark (25m x 10m) from coastal Vic and NSW (including Sydney Hawkesbury Sandstone region). Thick broad glossy dark green leaves paler below. Cream flowers in summer. Useful as a large windbreak or shade tree for a large garden. Tolerant of soil salinity. Frost and drought tolerant. Additional irrigation above natural rainfall may be required if growing conditions do not replicate the plant's natural occurrence. *Known to damage underground services, do not plant within 6 metres of any wastewater pipe.

Evergreen small multi trunked tree with silver grey powdery and pendulous branches (8m x 4m) from WA. Silver grey leaves on contrasting reddish stems. Loose clusters of hanging large pink to red flowers followed by large urn shaped fruit. Useful as a feature particularly in a bush garden. Suitable for a large container. Prefers a dry summer climate and can be unreliable in high humidity. Needs well drained soil. Drought tolerant. Tolerates light frosts. *Known to damage underground services, do not plant within 6 metres of any wastewater pipe.

Evergreen spreading tree with coarsely furrowed blackish bark (15m x 6m) from Qld & NSW (including Sydney Cumberland Plain). Dull green to grey green leaves. Terminal clusters of cream flowers. Useful as a shade tree or grouped for a windbreak. Tolerates heavy soils. Potentially invasive root system. Avoid planting close to structures. Frost and drought tolerant. *Known to damage underground services, do not plant within 6 metres of any wastewater pipe.

Evergreen medium to tall tree (30m x 8m) from Qld & NSW (including Sydney Cumberland Plain). Large oval grey-green dull leaves. Cream flowers in summer. Useful in large gardens for shade or windbreak. Potentially invasive root system. Avoid planting close to structures. Frost and drought tolerant. *Known to damage underground services, do not plant within 6 metres of any wastewater pipe.

Evergreen open crown tree with sometimes twisted and multi trunked form (6-10m x 8m) from NSW (including Sydney). Smooth white bark marked with 'scribbles' caused by insect activity. Broad lance shaped leaves. White flowers spasmodically from autumn to summer. Useful feature tree for informal gardens and shade tree. Attractive in group plantings and good tree for native shrub understorey. Prefers sandy soil and suitable for low fertility soils. Moderately wind and salt tolerant. Drought and frost tolerant. *Known to damage underground services, do not plant within 6 metres of any wastewater pipe.

Evergreen medium to large sized tree with smooth white powdery bark (20m x 8m) from NSW (including Sydney) & Vic. Useful as a feature or shade tree or multi-stemmed for a large informal bush garden. Responds well to coppicing to obtain multi-stemmed specimens. Tolerates shallow infertile soil. Susceptible to dropping limbs. Hybridisation has resulted in many sub-species. Frost and drought tolerant. *Known to damage underground services, do not plant within 6 metres of any wastewater pipe.

Evergreen medium sized tree with a spreading crown and fibrous grey bark; smooth on the upper branches (20m x 8m) from Qld & NSW (including Sydney Cumberland Plain). Broad lanceolate glossy green leaves. Cream flowers in summer. Useful for a shade tree or windbreak. Prefers clay soil. Frost and drought tolerant. *Known to damage underground services, do not plant within 6 metres of any wastewater pipe.

Evergreen multi- stemmed mallee form tree with smooth bark shedding in ribbons (3m x 1.5m) from sandstone regions of Sydney; NSW. Thick leathery leaves with hard abrupt points. Prominent sprays of cream flowers in winter and spring. Useful specimen or grouped particularly for an informal bush garden on poor sandy soil. May loose mallee form in fertile soils. Frost and drought tolerant. *Known to damage underground services, do not plant within 6 metres of any wastewater pipe.

Evergreen small tree with drooping branches (8m x 4m) from NSW (including Sydney Cumberland Plain). Dull green lanceolate leaves. White flowers in summer. Useful as a shade or feature tree in heavy soils. Bird attracting. Frost tolerant. Additional irrigation above natural rainfall may be required if growing conditions do not replicate natural occurrence. *Known to damage underground services, do not plant within 6 metres of any wastewater pipe.

Evergreen open crowned large tall stately tree with smooth trunk and persistent bark at the base.(30m + x 15m) from Qld and NSW (including Sydney). Long narrow drooping leaves. White flowers in summer. Suitable as a windbreak or tall tree on the largest gardens. Wind tolerant. Tolerant of light frosts. Potentially invasive root system. Avoid planting close to structures. Additional irrigation above natural rainfall may be required if growing conditions do not replicate natural occurrence. *Known to damage underground services, do not plant within 6 metres of any wastewater pipe.

Evergreen large tall open crowned tree (10-25m x 8m) from NSW (including Sydney). Matt grey bark marked with patches of pink or cream. Curved lanceolate leaves; pale underneath with drawn out point. White flowers in summer. Useful shade tree for dappled light and native shrub understorey particularly on infertile sandy soils and bog areas. Favourite food of Koalas. Drought and frost tolerant. *Known to damage underground services, do not plant within 6 metres of any wastewater pipe.
Indigenous (Qld & NSW (Sydney on swampy creek & estuary margins))

Evergreen branching tree with a heavy crown and rough bark (15m x 6m) from Qld and NSW (including Sydney). Large coarse leathery glossy dark green leaves. Profuse cream flowers in winter. Useful as a windbreak or shade tree particularly in a wet position. Tolerant of poorly drained saline soils. Potential to drop branches. Frost and drought tolerant. Additional irrigation above natural rainfall may be required if growing conditions do not replicate the plant's natural occurrence. *Known to damage underground services, do not plant within 6 metres of any wastewater pipe.

Evergreen tree with open crown of irregular branches and white smooth bark marked with 'scribbles' caused by insect activity (15m) from NSW Tablelands including western edge of Sydney. Greyish green long narrow leaves. White many stamen flowers in summer. Useful as shade tree in a large garden. Select and develop for straight trunk if desired when young. Drought tolerant. *Known to damage underground services, do not plant within 6 metres of any wastewater pipe.

Evergreen large tall straight tree (30-40m x 10m) with smooth bluish bark. Narrow lanceolate leaves; paler beneath. White flowers in summer. Useful for very large gardens in higher rainfall areas as a tall shade and specimen tree. Prefers fertile soil and slope locations. Drought tolerant in favourable growing conditions. Additional irrigation above natural rainfall may be required if growing conditions do not replicate the plant's natural occurrence. *Known to damage underground services, do not plant within 6 metres of any wastewater pipe.

Evergreen open crown tree with weeping branches and smooth white bark (12m x 8m) from NSW and Qld. Narrow yellow-green willow-like leaves. Creamy white flowers in summer. Useful for high rainfall areas as a shade or feature tree. Frost tolerant. *Known to damage underground services, do not plant within 6 metres of any wastewater pipe.

Evergreen tree with an irregular crown and black deeply furrowed bark (25m x 10m) from Qld; NSW (including Sydney Cumberland Plain) and Vic. Blue-grey weeping foliage. White or pink flowers in winter and spring. Useful in large gardens for shade; windbreak or as a feature for its contrasting colours. Frost and drought tolerant. *Known to damage underground services, do not plant within 6 metres of any wastewater pipe.
Indigenous (NSW ( Sydney sandstone on moist slopes); Vic and Tas.)

Evergreen variable open crowned tree (8-20m x 5m with size and form responding to soil quality) from NSW (including Sydney); Vic and Tas. Lanceolate; thick glossy leaves. White flowers in spring. Useful as a screen and for shade in informal gardens. Prefers sandy well drained soil with good rainfall. Frost tolerant. Additional irrigation above natural rainfall may be required if growing conditions do not replicate natural occurrence. *Known to damage underground services, do not plant within 6 metres of any wastewater pipe.
Indigenous (Qld; NSW (alluvial flats of Cumberland Plain Sydney) Vic & New Guinea)

Evergreen tall tree with open crown and smooth to mottled bark (40m x 10m) from Qld; NSW (including Cumberland Plains region Sydney); Vic. & New Guinea. Long and slender leaves tend to hang vertically. Cream flowers. Useful as an ornamental; for shade or as a windbreak in very large gardens. Frost tolerant. Additional irrigation above natural rainfall may be required if growing conditions do not replicate the plant's natural occurrence. *Known to damage underground services, do not plant within 6 metres of any wastewater pipe.

Evergreen upright; dense shrub (1.5m x 1.5m) from Japan. Broad oval leaves with a broken margin of deep yellow. Small greenish-white flowers usually followed by round pink fruits. Useful for background; screen; accent or clipped feature. Tolerates heat; wind and salt spray. Frost tolerant.

Evergreen bushy shrub (2.5m x 2m) from Western Asia. Large grey green leaves. Flat top clusters of purple flowers in spring. Useful as a fence screen; background to lower growing shrubs or tall understorey. Prefers a protected shady position. Cut back flowered stems to above the previous season's growth immediately after flowering. Frost tolerant. Drought sensitive.

Evergreen upright shrub (1.5m x 1m) from the Balkans. Clustered spirals of grey green leaves. Large umbels of yellow green flowers with greenish bracts at the ends of branches. Useful in a perennial garden or mixed with shrubbery. Cut off spent flowers above junction with previous year's growth. Drought and frost tolerant.
Indigenous (Vic; NSW ( in or near rainforests Sydney Illawarra zone) Qld & Papua New Guinea.)

Evergreen large spreading shrub; often multi-trunked (5m x 3m) from in or near rainforests of Vic; NSW (including Sydney Illawarra zone); Qld & Papua New Guinea. Glossy dark green leaves on slender zigzag arching branches. Foliage turns coppery red in winter. Cream perfumed flowers in summer followed by edible green urn shaped fruit. Useful as a feature foliage plant or background screen. Prefers mulched well composted soil. Frost and drought sensitive. Additional irrigation above natural rainfall may be required if growing conditions do not replicate the plant's natural occurrence.

Evergreen upright small shrub (0.8m x 0.8m) from South Africa. Deep cut grey green leaves. Large heads of daisy-like bright yellow flowers in summer. Useful for its colour and foliage contrast with perennials; between shrubs as a fill-in plant or as a small hedge. Requires perfect drainage in an open sunny position. Frost sensitive. Drought tolerant.

Evergreen rounded dense shrub (3m x 2m) from Japan. Large glossy green palmate leaves on long petioles. Branching heads of creamy white flowers followed by small black berries. Useful for its foliage as a border plant or for a tropical themed garden. Prefers a partial shade position. Frost sensitive.

Evergreen dense bushy shrub (2.5m x 2m) from South America. Deep green leaves with white underside. Aromatic dark red flowers with white edged petals in summer followed by edible green; yellow fleshed fruits. Two plants growing nearby are necessary for fruit set. Useful for a screen; as an espalier for a sunny wall or as a feature for edible fruit. Prefers an alkaline soil. Requires ample water in hot summer temperatures. Frost sensitive. *Known to damage underground services, do not plant within 6 metres of any wastewater pipe.

Evergreen small bushy shrub (0.5m x 0.5m) from South Africa. Slightly hairy oval bright green leaves. Blue daisy-like yellow centred flowers on long stalks throughout the year. Useful for colour in perennial gardens and low borders. Prune to maintain shape. Drought and frost sensitive.

Cool season coarse textured tufted perennial turf grass spreading by erect tillers from Europe. Flat dull green leaf blade on the upper surface; glossy on the underside. Erect nodding flowering panicles. Numerous cultivars available. Useful in areas where coarse texture and higher cutting height is acceptable. Preferred cutting height 35-50mm depending on variety. Not suitable for animal owners or low cutting. Tolerates moderate shade. Tolerant of warm summer temperatures and cool winters. Deep root system with moderate drought tolerance once established. Frost tolerant.

Evergreen tuft forming fine textured perennial grass (0.3m x 0.2m) from Europe. Radiating clump of blue green to silvery white soft needle-like leaves. Fine panicles of spikelets in summer turning into buff brown seed heads. Useful for a border; edging; specimen in groups or mass planting. Plant densely for solid cover. Prune foliage back one third in spring. Needs well drained soil. Sensitive to high humidity. Frost tolerant. Drought tolerant in partial shade.

Deciduous often multi trunked small tree (4-6m x 4m) with edible fruit and shallow spreading root system from western Asia. Broad rough textured lobed leaves. Flowers hidden on the inside of a fleshy receptacle which becomes the fruit. Useful for its fruit; shade or distinctive leaf. Popular varieties include 'White Adriatic'; 'Brown Turkey' and 'Black Genoa'. Needs a mild warm climate. Prefers deep heavy soil in full sun. Requires fertilising in spring and ample water in the growing season. Drought sensitive. *Known to damage underground services, do not plant within 6 metres of any wastewater pipe.

Evergreen fast growing self climbing vine with clinging rootlets (7m) from China; Japan and Vietnam. Crinkly heart shaped juvenile leaves on a tracery of fine stems. Large leathery adult leaves. Useful for covering masonry or concrete vertical surfaces or for creating quick topiary. Tolerant of all soil types. Suitable for sun or shade. Aggressive grower requiring plenty of space or regular pruning to control. Frost and drought tolerant.

Upright clump forming perennial with fleshy swollen roots (1m x 0.5m) from Europe and Asia. Deeply cut fern-like leaves. Mostly leafless stems of crowded heads of tiny white sometimes pink flowers in summer. Useful mixed with perennials or as background border particularly in a dry location. Prefers well drained soil in full sun. Frost and drought tolerant.

Evergreen fast growing tree with a densely branching crown (30m x 5m) from Qld and NSW. Large compound pinnate leaves. Sprays of white flowers with brown centres followed by large prickly pods opening into boat shaped segments. Useful specimen or shade tree for a large garden in warm coastal areas. Prefers well composted soil in an open sunny position. Drought and frost sensitive.

Deciduous fast growing shrub with irregular branches tending towards an arching form (2.5m x 2.5m) from China. Deep green pointed leaves. Large yellow bell shaped flowers in spring precede the leaves. Useful for colour in winter and mass planting for erosion control on banks. Stems readily root at the tips. Remove old canes at the ground after flowering. Frost tolerant.

Evergreen small compact tree with a shallow root system (2-3m x 1m) from China. Dark green glossy leaves. Small waxy white scented flowers in spring followed by spherical edible orange fruit. Useful for courtyards; topiary; pots; standards and hedging. Prefers full sun. Keep well watered when fruit is forming. Fertilise spring and late summer or every 8 weeks if growing in pots. Prefers light well drained soil. Mulch under the canopy and ensure mulch does not touch the trunk. Frost and drought sensitive.

Evergreen small compact tree with a shallow root system (1-2m x 0.8m) from China. Long narrow dark green glossy leaves. Small waxy white scented flowers in spring followed by oval to oblong fruit. Useful for courtyards; topiary; pots; standards and hedging. Prefers full sun. Keep well watered when fruit is forming. Fertilise spring and late summer or every 8 weeks if growing in pots. Prefers light well drained soil. Mulch under the canopy and ensure mulch does not touch the trunk. Frost and drought sensitive.

Deciduous spreading tree (20m x 12m) from North America. Dark green leaves whitish grey beneath divided into 5-9 oval leaflets turning purple in autumn. Useful as a specimen or shade tree. Very fast growing. Frost tolerant. *Known to damage underground services, do not plant within 6 metres of any wastewater pipe.

Evergreen tree (15m x 7m) forming an umbrella shaped crown from Europe and the UK. Compound leaves with oval leaflets golden yellow in spring and autumn. Deep yellow stems with conspicuous black buds in winter. Inconspicuous flowers. Useful for a specimen; shade and autumn foliage colour. Tolerates warm conditions without leaf burn if moisture is adequate. Potentially invasive root system. Avoid planting close to structures. Frost tolerant. Drought sensitive. *Known to damage underground services, do not plant within 6 metres of any wastewater pipe.

Evergreen small tree with grey bark (8m x 4m) from South East Asia. Compound pale green leaves with curly edges and silver beneath. White flowers in long panicles at the branch tips in spring. Prefers deep soils and tolerates wet soils. Frost tolerant. Drought sensitive. *Known to damage underground services, do not plant within 6 metres of any wastewater pipe.
Non indigenous (South Eastern Europe & Asia Minor. Select form developed in Australia.)

Deciduous vigorous spreading tree with a symmetrical crown (10m x 7m). Select form of F.oxycarpa developed in Australia from South Eastern Europe and Asia Minor. Lacy pinnate compound leaves occurring in whorls along the branches turning purple red in autumn. Useful as a specimen or shade tree. Frost tolerant. *Known to damage underground services, do not plant within 6 metres of any wastewater pipe.

Deciduous uniformally upright tree becoming broader with age (13m x 8m) from North America. Dark green pinnate leaves with 5-9 leaflets turning deep burgundy red in autumn. Inconspicuous flowers and thought to be seedless. Useful specimen or shade tree for a large garden. Prefers moist well drained soil in full sun. Tolerant of urban pollution and moderate drought once established. Frost tolerant. *Known to damage underground services, do not plant within 6 metres of any wastewater pipe.

Evergreen variable shrub sometimes semi-climbing (0.75-2m x 0.3-1m) from South America. Pendant mainly bell-shaped often bicoloured flowers on leafy stems from spring through to autumn. Flowers may be red; pink; white; mauve or variations of those colours. Useful close to the house against a wall for support; in containers or baskets. Brittle stem growth needs protection from wind. Prefers fertile moist soil in a partial shade position. Responds well to pruning hard after flowering. Many varieties frost sensitive. Drought sensitive.

Evergreen short-lived mound forming perennial (0.7m x 1m) from the USA. Narrow slightly lobed hairy leaves. Daisy-like flowers with a central yellow or purple disc and outer petals in combination shades of orange; burgundy; red or yellow. Useful for colour in the perennial garden or tall background to other annuals. Remove old flowers. Cut back to near ground level after flowering. Needs dry sandy well drained soil. Tolerates poor soil and strong winds. Drought and frost tolerant.

Evergreen bushy shrub (1.5m x 1.5m) from China. Glossy elliptic bright green leaves. Fragrant white flowers 10-12cm diameter in summer. Useful for its fragrance close to the house; as a hedge or container plant. Prefers partial shade in well drained acid loam. Frost and drought sensitive.

Evergreen low dense spreading shrub (0.3m x 0.8m). Dwarf form of G. augusta from China. Small leaves. Fragrant white flowers in summer. Useful as a specimen for its perfume or mass planted as a groundcover or understorey. Suitable as a container plant. Prefers partial shade in well drained acid loam. Sensitive to over watering. Frost and drought sensitive.

Evergreen loose vase shaped perennial with wand-like flowering stalks (1m x 1m) from North America. Small lance shaped leaves. Delicate pink flowers on long stems. Useful as a specimen; mass planted and for perennial borders. Avoid root disturbance. Tends to self sow. Improved cultivars available. Frost and drought tolerant.

Evergreen, hybridised, trailing or clump-forming perennial (0.2 m x 0.5 m) from South Africa. Dull, olive-green leaves and silvery-white underneath. Large, daisy-like flowers in a variety of colours including orange, yellow, bronze, pink, tan and white in combinations of singles, doubles, striped or splashed with colour. Flowers when the sun is out. Useful for mass planting or groundcover, edging, bedding or containers. Needs full sun and prefers sandy soil. Hardy. Potential to invade bushland. Drought and frost tolerant.

Evergreen small tree with a spreading crown and pendulous habit (10m x 4m) from Qld; NSW; Vic and SA. Linear olive green leaves. Insignificant white flowers. Useful as a screen; specimen and shade tree. Tolerates a wide range of moisture levels. Frost and drought tolerant.

Evergreen moderately vigorous twining climber with wiry stems (4 m) from North America. Sparse oval lance shaped leaves. Clusters of fragrant funnel shaped yellow flowers from late spring to summer. Useful for covering a trellis; fence or other structures where support is provided. All parts of the plant are toxic. Wind tolerant. Frost and drought tolerant.

Evergreen slender tree with a short trunk and weeping branches (5m x 3m) from Sicily and Sardinia. Narrow sparse leaves. Terminal clusters of fragrant pea shaped flowers from late spring to summer. Useful as a feature or mixed with other shrubs for its form and colour display. Thrives in poor sandy soils. Sensitive to poorly drained soils. Potential bushland invader. Drought and frost tolerant.

Evergreen upright perennial with long flowering stems (0.3m x 0.5m) from Africa. Deeply lobed leaves arranged in a basal rosette. Daisy-like flowers from spring to autumn in many variable colours often yellow; pink; scarlet or orange. Useful as a cut flower; bedding plant for a border or in clumps for colour. Requires deep loamy soil and perfect drainage. Performs best in raised beds. Frost and drought sensitive.

Deciduous long-lived tree; upright when young spreading with age. (20m x 7m) from China. Fan shaped two lobed bright green leaves. Separate male and female plants. Male plant is preferable as female fruit has an unpleasant odour. Useful as a shade or feature tree. Prefers moist deep fertile soil. Can be susceptible to borer attack in Sydney. Frost tolerant. Drought sensitive.

Group of corm perennials (1m x 0.3m) from Europe and Africa. Each corm produces a fan of erect stiff sword shaped leaves on the basal part of the flower stem. Erect spikes of up to 30 funnel shaped flowers arranged on opposite sides of the stem in summer. Wide range of colours and flower forms through extensive hybridisation. Useful in clumps and drifts in the perennial garden. Valued for cut flowers. Corms require lifting and treatment after flowering. Drought sensitive.

Deciduous tree with thornless trunk and upright ascending branches then spreading horizontally (20m x 5m) from North America. Fernlike fine textured glossy dark green leaves turning yellow in autumn. Insignificant greenish yellow flowers sometimes followed by brown twisted pods. Cultivar G. triacanthos 'Sunburst' has yellow foliage. Useful as a specimen or for providing filtered shade. Hardy. Tolerant of poor soils and salinity. Potentially invasive root system. Avoid planting close to structures. Potential to invade bushland. Frost and drought tolerant.
Indigenous (Qld & NSW (Sydney in moist sheltered woodlands & gullies))

Evergreen bushy tree of variable size (6-12m x 4-8m) from Qld and NSW (including Sydney). Shiny leaves in 2 rows like a compound leaf. Insignificant flowers followed by fruit shaped like a wrapped cheese. Useful as a shade or feature tree in a protected position or rainforest garden. Prefers well composted soil. Frost sensitive. Moderately drought tolerant. Additional irrigation above natural rainfall may be required if growing conditions do not replicate the plant's natural occurrence.
Indigenous (Qld; Vic & NSW (including Sydney on Hawkesbury Sandstone))

Evergreen erect shrub (1.5m x 1.5m) from Qld; Vic and NSW (including Sydney on Hawkesbury Sandstone). Digitate leaflets. Yellow pea flowers in spring. Useful mixed with small shrubs or understorey particularly in a bush garden. Requires good drainage and partial shade. Frost and drought tolerant.
Indigenous (Vic; NSW (Sydney Hawkesbury Sandstone & Cumberland Plain); ACT & Qld)

Evergreen trailing groundcover (0.05m x 0.5m) often rooting at the nodes from Vic; NSW (including Sydney Hawkesbury Sandstone and Cumberland Plain); ACT and Qld. Erect spoon shaped leaves dark green above silvery below forming small basal rosettes and also occurring along the flower stem. Bright yellow flowers on long slender stalks in spring and summer. Useful groundcover for rock or gravel gardens or understorey particularly in a bush garden. Prefers well drained sandy soil. Tolerates shade. Frost and drought tolerant.

Evergreen shrub or groundcover with variable forms from prostrate to semi-erect (0.3-1.5m x 0.8m) from eastern Australia (including Sydney). Toothed soft glossy ovate leaves. Yellow flowers in spring; summer and autumn. Useful as a fast growing shrub; groundcover or for gully erosion control. Bird attracting. Tolerates poor soil and temporary inundation. Prefers partial shade. Frost and drought tolerant.
Non indigenous (Qld; NSW; Vic; Tas; SA & WA.)

Evergreen perennial (0.25mm x 0.25mm) from Qld; NSW; Vic; Tas; SA & WA. Deeply toothed oblong to wedge shaped leaves forming rosettes. Bright yellow flowers on branching slender stems. Useful for a rock and gravel garden or understorey particularly in a bush garden. Prefers well drained sandy soil. Tolerates shade. Frost tolerant.
Indigenous (Qld; NSW (including Sydney); Vic; Tas & SA)

Evergreen spreading open shrub with a vigorous suckering habit (2.5m x 3m) from Qld; NSW (including Sydney); Vic; Tas and SA. Trifoliate clover-like glossy light green leaves. Short loose spikes of bright yellow pea flowers with red centres in spring. Useful fast growing screen or tall loose hedge for large gardens. Tolerant of a wide range of growing conditions. Tolerates full sun preferring some shade. Frost and drought tolerant.

Evergreen bushy shrub or tree (4m x 4m) from China. Slow growing when young. Dark green glossy leaves. Bark sheds to a smooth satiny tan trunk. White saucer shaped flower with a golden yellow stamen centre. Flowers through winter to spring. Useful for a feature; screen or small shade tree. Frost sensitive.

Evergreen erect shrub (3m x 2m) from Qld. Dark green shiny obovate leaves. Deep red tubular waxy flowers in summer followed by club shaped woody capsules. Useful feature; screen or hedge for its foliage and showy flowers. Bird attracting. Prefers well composted soil in a partly shaded warm protected position. Tolerates pruning and suckers readily. Frost and drought sensitive.
Non indigenous (Selected cultivar of G. nana subsp. abbreviata & G. 'Sid Cadwell' from Australia)

Evergreeen compact low growing shrub (1m x 2.5m). Selected cultivar between G. nana subsp. abbreviata and G. 'Sid Cadwell'. Bright green finely divided leaves. Large racemes of metallic pink flowers for most of the year. Useful specimen or mass planted. Tolerant of high summer temperatures. Bird attracting. Tolerates light frost.

Evergreen sprawling groundcover grevillea (0.3m x 4m). A selected cultivar between G. rivularis from NSW and hybrid G. Poorinda Peter. Divided leaves with bronze to red young growth. Red toothbrush-like flowers throughout the year. Useful for rapidly covering large areas or banks. Bird attracting. Frost and drought tolerant.
Non indigenous (Hybrid of G. rosmarinifolia from NSW & G. lavandulaceae from SA)

Evergreen erect shrub (2m x 2m). Hybrid between G. rosmarinifolia from NSW and G. lavandulaceae from SA. Narrow linear leaves with a fine pungent point. Reddish spider-like flowers in winter and spring. Useful screen; mass planted or amongst other shrubs particularly in a bush garden. Bird attracting. Needs well drained soil in full sun. Prune regularly to compact form. Frost and drought tolerant.
Non indigenous (Hybrd of G. lanigera from Vic & G. lavandulaceae from NSW; Vic & SA)

Evergreen low spreading shrub with arching branches (1.5m x 2-3m). Hybrid between G. lanigera from Vic and G. lavandulaceae from NSW; Vic and SA. Linear grey-green hairy leaves with a pungent point. Small spidery-like clusters of red and cream flowers from late winter to spring. Useful specimen or mass planted particularly in a bush garden. Prefers well drained soil in a sunny position. Tolerates light shade. Frost and drought tolerant.
Non indigenous (Cultivar of G. longistyla from NSW & G. vestita from Qld.)

Evergreen spreading shrub (2m x 3m). Cultivar of G. longistyla from NSW and G. vestita from Qld. Narrow dark green leaves. Terminal spikes of bright red waxy flowers. Useful feature or massed for its large flowers and attractive foliage. Good cut flower. Bird attracting. Prefers well drained soil in full sun to partial shade. Frost sensitive.
Non indigenous (Hybrid between G. pteridifolia & G. banksii both from Qld)

Evergreen vigorous tall shrub (4m x 3m) with a light open texture. Probably a hybrid between G. pteridifolia and G. banksii both from Qld. Dark green deeply pinnate lobed leaves silvery underneath with silky hair covered young stems. Semi-cylindrical racemes of apricot flowers with an orange yellow style for most of the year. Useful for its colour and texture among other shrubs or as background for smaller shrubs. Bird attracting. Needs well drained soil. Frost and drought sensitive.
Non indigenous (Hybrid between G. longifolia x G. caleyi)

Evergreen fast growing tall shrub (4m x 3m) with branches held horizontally. Presumed garden hybrid of G. longifolia and G. caleyi. Long slender deeply serrated leaves bronze red when young turning mid green. Red brush-like flowers on the tips and along branches from winter to spring. Useful for quick screening or background plant. Bird attracting. Can become top heavy and blow over. Prune hard to encourage base branching. Frost and drought tolerant.
Non indigenous (Natural hybrid from Braidwood NSW)

Evergreen vigorous suckering groundcover (0.4m x 4m). Thought to be a natural hybrid between G. arenaria and G. lanigera from Braidwood NSW. Dull green broadly linear leaves. Clusters of pink and cream inconspicuous flowers. Useful groundcover over large areas; bank stabiliser and excellent for suppressing weed growth due to its suckering habit. Tolerant of a wide range of conditions. Frost and drought tolerant.
Non indigenous (Hybrid between G. sessilis & G. banksii from Qld)

Evergreen medium to large quick growing shrub with an open habit (3m x 2m). Hybrid between G. sessilis and G. banksii both from Qld. Grey pinnately lobed leaves. Cylindrical racemes of pale pink flowers with orange styles all year round. Useful as a feature for its long flowering period; screen or background for smaller shrubs. Attracts honey-eating birds.. Can be pruned hard to improve form. Tolerates light to medium frosts.
Non indigenous (Thought to be cultivar of G. banksii & G. whiteana; from Qld)

Evergreen tall shrub or small tree (4-5m x 3m). Deeply divided green leaves. Thought to be cultivar of G. banksii and G. whiteana; both from Qld. Deeply divided green leaves. Large soft cream flowers throughout most of the year. Useful feature; screen or hedge for its extended flowering period. Bird attracting. Needs well drained soil in full sun. Tolerates light frost.

species: Grevillea Ned Kelly Syn G Masons Hybrid

Grevillea Ned Kelly Syn G Masons Hybrid
Grevillea Ned Kelly Syn G Masons Hybrid
value: Non indigenous (Hybrid between G. banksii from Qld & G. bipinnatifida from WA)

species: Grevillea Ned Kelly Syn G Masons Hybrid
Grevillea Ned Kelly Syn G Masons Hybrid
value: Evergreen vigorous quick growing bushy shrub (2m x 3m). Hybrid between G. banksii from Qld and G bipinnatifida from WA. Bright green lobed leaves. Large orange red flowers with red styles aging to pinkish orange throughout most of the year. Useful as a feature; screen or background for smaller shrubs. Attracts honey-eating birds. Prefers a sunny well drained position. Growth habit can become untidy with age. Prune regularly or severely to rejuvenate. Tolerates light to medium frost.
Non indigenous (Hybrid between G. laurifolia from NSW & G. willissii from Vic)

Evergreen low growing and vigorously spreading groundcover (0.2m x 3m). Hybrid between G. laurifolia from NSW & G. willissii from Vic. Variable and deeply divided olive green leaves with bronze purple new growth. Purple-red toothbrush shaped flowers held above the foliage in summer. Useful groundcover for large areas particularly for banks and spilling over walls. Mulch well to keep weeds suppressed. Frost and drought tolerant.
Non indigenous (Hybrid between G. longifolia from NSW & G. tetragonoloba from WA)

Evergreen dense spreading shrub (3m x 4m). Hybrid thought to be from G. longifolia from NSW and G. tetragonoloba from WA. Pinnately lobed leaves on horizontal branches. Bright red toothbrush like flowers held horizontally. Useful as a screen; feature; informal hedge or background. Bird attracting. Hardy. Can be pruned hard to improve wind tolerance and form. Frost and drought tolerant.
Non indigenous (Hybrid between G. banksii from Qld & G. bipinnatifida from WA)

Evergreen low growing compact shrub (1.5m x 1.5m). Hybrid between G. banksii from Qld and G. bipinnatifida from WA. Glossy bright green leaves divided into lobes. Pendulous red tooth-brush-like flowers throughout the year. Useful as a low hedge or for mass or group plantings or with mixed shrubs. Bird attracting. Prefers sandy loam in full sun. Frost tolerant.
Non indigenous (Hybrid of G. banksii White Form from Qld & G. bipinnatifida from WA)

Evergreen fast growing vigorous shrub (1.5m x 2m). Hybrid between G. banksii White Form from Qld and G. bipinnatifida from WA and sharing same parentage as G. 'Robyn Gordon'. Bright green heavily divided leaves. Large apricot-orange racemes of flowers opening in succession over most of the year. Useful feature; screen or hedge for its extended flowering period. Bird attracting. Prefers well drained soil in full sun. Tolerates heavy pruning if necessary. Tolerates light frost.

Evergreen compact rounded shrub (2.5m x 3m) from NSW. Dull green soft oblong leaves. Green or red hairy flowers with a red or green style. Flowers for most of the year. Useful screen and very durable for surviving tough conditions. Bird attracting. Tolerates a wide range of soil types. Frost and drought tolerant.

Evergreen fast growing spreading shrub with horizontal branches (3m x 3m) from NSW (including Sydney). Linear sometimes slightly toothed leaves white underneath. Red toothbrush-like flowers occur most of the year. Useful specimen or screen plant. Bird attracting. Frost and drought tolerant.
Non indigenous (Rainforests of Qld & Papua New Guinea)

Evergreen small to medium tree (8-10m x 4m) from rainforests of Qld and Papua New Guinea. Rich green leaves with rusty bronze sheen on the underside of new growth. Lobed juvenile leaves. Tight clusters of perfumed white flowers in spring and summer. Useful for a feature or shade tree. Bird attracting. Protect from wind. Frost and drought sensitive.

Evergreen well branched shrub (3m x 2m) from south east Qld. Dark green finely lobed pinnate leaves. Erect cylindrical red flowers throughout the year. Cream form available. Useful as a screen or feature. Bird attracting. Moderately drought tolerant once established. Frost sensitive.

Evergreen dense spreading shrub (1.5m x 2.5m). Rare endangered species from the Northern Tablelands NSW. Softly-textured much divided grey-green leaves. Dark red toothbrush-like flowers for a large part of the year. Useful as a specimen or mixed in shrubberies particularly in a bush garden. Bird attracting. Needs well drained soil in full sun to partial shade. Frost and drought tolerant.
Indigenous (Endemic to Sydney Hawkesbury Sandstone regions)

Open rounded shrub (1.5m x 1.5m). Endemic to Sydney Hawkesbury Sandstone NSW. Stiff oblong leaves with silver hairs. Dense terminal heads of woolly grey flowers for most of the year. Useful specimen or massed for its unusual flower and silvery foliage particularly in a bush garden. Prefers sandy well drained soil in full sun. Frost and drought tolerant.

Evergreen broad spreading shrub (3m x 4m) from NSW (endemic to Sydney on Hawkesbury sandstone). Hairy deeply divided pinnate leaves with pink new growth. Red toothbrush-like flowers late winter to summer. Useful specimen or grouped particularly in a bush garden. Bird attracting. Needs well drained sandy soil. Prune to maintain compact shape. Frost and drought tolerant.

Evergreen low mounding shrub (1m x 1.5m) from NSW. Narrow elliptical leaves. Pendulous clusters of dark red almost black flowers in late winter and spring. Useful hardy fill-in shrub particularly in a bush garden. Frost and drought tolerant.

Evergreen shrub with rounded base and upright flowering canes (2m x 2m) from WA. Glaucous soft linear leaves. Erect clusters of pinkish white flowers on extended leafy branches most of the year. Useful as a feature or accent for its unusual habit particularly in a bush garden. Requires well-drained sandy or gravely soil. Frost and drought tolerant.

Evergreen spreading shrub (1.5m x 1.5m) from NSW (including Sydney). Stiff needle-like leaves ending in a sharp point. Yellow-green or red spider-like flowers at the ends of branches in spring. Many cultivated varieties including prostrate form available. Useful as a low screen; groundcover; mixed with other shrubs or specimen. Bird attracting. Hardy. Frost and drought tolerant.

Evergreen prostrate groundcover (0.1 x 2m) from upper Blue Mountains NSW. Ovate leathery green leaves. Dark red toothbrush-like flowers on long trailing stems. Useful as a vigorous groundcover or to spill over sloping banks. Bird attracting. Prefers a location of high elevation. Frost tolerant. Additional irrigation above natural rainfall may be required if growing conditions do not replicate the plant's natural occurrence.

Evergreen rounded shrub with many variable forms (0.3-1m x 1m) from NSW; Vic and SA. Grey-green linear to lanceolate leaves. Semi-erect spider-like clusters usually pink or red sometimes cream flowers in winter and spring. Useful mass planted or amongst other shrubs particularly in a bush garden. Prostrate form 'Mt Tamboritha' is useful for groundcover. Bird attracting. Requires well drained soil in full sun or dappled shade. Performs best in drier climates. Can be sensitive to high summer humidity. Frost and drought tolerant.

Evergreen variable open to low growing shrub (1.5-2.5 x 2m) from Qld and NSW (including Sydney Hawkesbury Sandstone regions). Long linear leaves covered with silver-silky hairs on the underside. White spider-like flower with style turning red with age. Useful as a screen; informal hedge or amongst shrubs especially in a bush garden. Bird attracting. Frost tolerant. Additional irrigation above natural rainfall may be required if growing conditions do not replicate natural occurrence.

Evergreen erect fast growing shrub (3m x 3m) from Qld. Fine slender deep green foliage on reddish stems. Erect loose clusters of orange to red waxy flowers in upper leaf axils in late winter to early summer. Useful as a feature or in group planting for its neat open habit and decorative flowers. Bird attracting. Prefers a well drained sunny position with protection from prevailing winds. Moderately frost tolerant.

Evergreen fast growing spreading to erect shrub (4m x 3m) from southern NSW. Dull green entire leaves. Pink toothbrush-like flowers in late winter to summer. Useful specimen; screen or addition to a bush garden. Bird attracting. Tolerates coastal conditions. Prefers well drained soil in full sun. Requires regular pruning to maintain shape. Frost tolerant.

species: Grevillea obtusifolia syn. Grevillea thelemanniana ssp. obtusifolia

Grevillea obtusifolia syn. Grevillea thelemanniana ssp. obtusifolia
